name: Dysfibrinogenemia
description: Rare inherited disorder characterized by qualitatively abnormal fibrinogen that may cause bleeding, thrombosis, or remain asymptomatic. Unique among coagulation disorders in its paradoxical presentation with either hemorrhage or thrombosis depending on the specific mutation.

fibrinogen_structure.structure: Hexamer with 2 each of Aα, Bβ, and γ chains
fibrinogen_structure.function: Thrombin cleaves fibrinopeptides A and B to form fibrin monomers that polymerize into clot

mutation_effects.bleeding_phenotype: Mutations affecting fibrin polymerization or crosslinking
mutation_effects.thrombotic_phenotype: Mutations causing impaired thrombin binding, plasminogen binding, or increased thrombin generation
mutation_effects.asymptomatic: Many mutations have no clinical consequence

clinical_features.wound_healing: Impaired wound healing in some variants

fibrinogen_discrepancy.interpretation: Discrepancy between functional and antigenic levels is key diagnostic clue

diagnosis.confirmatory: Genetic testing for FGA, FGB, FGG mutations

fibrinogen_replacement.target: Fibrinogen >100 mg/dL for procedures, >150 mg/dL for major surgery

surgery_perioperative.thrombotic_phenotype: Balance thrombosis prevention with bleeding risk

pregnancy.postpartum: Monitor for both bleeding and thrombosis

clinical_pearls: Thrombin time is most sensitive screening test - always prolonged in dysfibrinogenemia
Discrepancy between functional (low) and antigenic (normal) fibrinogen = dysfibrinogenemia
Same mutation can cause different phenotypes in family members - variable expressivity
Most cases are asymptomatic - discovered incidentally on routine coagulation testing
learning_objectives: Explain how dysfibrinogenemia can cause both bleeding and thrombosis
Describe the laboratory findings characteristic of dysfibrinogenemia
Outline management strategies for different dysfibrinogenemia phenotypes
